pullRequest.body:
Give conditions for prods to converge uniformly to a tprod.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

- [x] depends on: #16546

nodes.body:
### PR summary [a31112cb84](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13349/commits/a31112cb84d286384138bea82e69c3e0f1d8660c)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Topology.UniformSpace.MultipliableTendstoUniformly` (new file)|2208|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Complex.tendstoUniformlyOn_tsum_log_one_add`
`+ TendstoUniformlyOn.comp_cexp`
`+ TendstoUniformlyOn.eventually_forall_le`
`+ TendstoUniformlyOn.eventually_forall_lt`
`+ UniformContinuousOn.comp_tendstoUniformlyOn_eventually`
`+ tendstoLocallyUniformlyOn_tprod_nat_one_add`
`+ tendstoUniformlyOn_tprod_nat_one_add`
`+ tendstoUniformlyOn_tprod_of_clog`
`+ tendstouniformlyOn_iff_restrict`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#16543~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#16546~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#15398~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
I have this result `le_of_TendstoUniformlyOn_le_right` which I expect is true more generally/ has an easier proof, but I'm not sure of a good way to do this, any ideas?

> Does this review get you off the ground? It seems like there's a lot of legwork left yet before it's ready for primetime. If you need more suggestions, ping me again.

Yes this is really useful, thank you!
@CBirkbeck are you clear how to proceed?

> @CBirkbeck are you clear how to proceed?

Yes I think so, thank you! (Sorry I only just saw all these messages/emails in my inbox).
Does this review get you off the ground? It seems like there's a lot of legwork left yet before it's ready for primetime. If you need more suggestions, ping me again.
This is as far as I got before stopping for dinner.

Hi Chris,

I hate to say this, but I think it would ease the task of refereeing your PR's a great deal if you could internalize the Mathlib coding conventions a bit more, and pay more attention to proof-reading your code before submission to simplify and tighten up the arguments. Please get into the habit of thinking, "is this the best name for this variable? are these brackets, type-ascriptions, etc, needed?"

1. This doesn't have anything to do with the `atTop` filter on `ι`, right? Please generalize.
2. This doesn't have anything to do with `MetricSpace`, right? Please generalize. The proof probably goes through [tendstoUniformlyOn_iff_tendstoUniformly_comp_coe](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/UniformSpace/UniformConvergence.html#tendstoUniformlyOn_iff_tendstoUniformly_comp_coe) and should go in that file.

This is pretty similar to [Filter.Tendsto.eventually_le_const](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Order/OrderClosed.html#Filter.Tendsto.eventually_le_const). I would use that as a basis from which to determine hypotheses and the form of your statement.

I wouldn't use `∀ x : K`, but rather `∀ x ∈ K` since `K` is a set.

So maybe I'm being stupid, but I'm struggling to meaningfully generalise this. One can do something like: 
```

lemma TendstoUniformlyOn_Eventually_le_const (f : ι → α → β) [NormedAddGroup β] {p : Filter ι}
    {g : α → β} {K : Set α} {T V : ℝ} (htv : T < V)
    (hf : TendstoUniformlyOn f g p K) (hg : ∀ x, x ∈ K → ‖g x‖ ≤ T) :
    ∀ᶠ (n : ι) in p, ∀ x, x ∈ K → ‖f n x‖ ≤ V := by
```
This is more generall but also more restrictive than what we have. I also don't quite know how to in effect remove the metric space condition and replace it with something like the hyp of [Filter.Tendsto.eventually_le_const](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Order/OrderClosed.html#Filter.Tendsto.eventually_le_const)

I had originally been thinking of something like this (but perhaps it's too much to hope for):
```lean
import Mathlib

theorem foo {ι : Type z} {α : Type u} {γ : Type w} [UniformSpace α] [LinearOrder α]
    [ClosedIciTopology α] {l : Filter ι} {f : ι → γ → α} {g : γ → α} {u v : α} (hv : v < u) (s : Set γ)
    (hg : ∀ x ∈ s, g x ≤ v) (h : TendstoUniformlyOn f g l s) :
    ∀ᶠ (i : ι) in l, (∀ x ∈ s, f i x ≤ u) := by
  sorry
```
Maybe @ADedecker  can specify what is the right generalization of `Filter.Tendsto.eventually_le_const` to `TendstoUniformlyOn`.

Sorry for the delay. I'm having some troubles seeing the proper setup here (in fact it reminds me quite a lot of what Jireh and I discussed for the purpose of Dini's theorem). 

I *think* that Jireh's version cannot work, because if you start from an entourage (i.e element of the uniformity) `E` such that the corresponding ball around `v` stays smaller than `u`, then I don't see how you would deduce anything about the `E`-ball centered at some `g x ≤ v`.

Regarding Chris's version about normed groups, I think this is rather a consequence more than a generalization: by applying [UniformContinuous.comp_tendstoUniformlyOn](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/UniformSpace/UniformConvergence.html#UniformContinuous.comp_tendstoUniformlyOn) to the norm function (*) this follows from the real case.

(*) We should really have something like `UniformContinuousOn.norm`

Now, as to what should be done here, one solution is restricting to ordered uniform groups: then you know that balls for different points are just translations of each other, and so you can do things concretely (feel free to ask if that's not clear). As usual, this as the quite annoying downside of excluding `NNReal`, but I do think it is a fact of life that the key topological properties of `NNReal` comes from the fact that it's a subset of `Real`... I can try to think more about it, but for now that's all I can see.

Yes, it also reminded me of our discussion of Dini's theorem.

> ordered uniform groups

What do you mean by this exactly @ADedecker ? `[UniformGroup G] [LinearOrder G] [OrderTopology G]`, or something else? I think those hypotheses should be sufficient.

Yes sorry, I forgot the very important linearity hypothesis, which cannot be avoided for `<` to be something meaningful. I think here we cannot do any generalization towards [NormedLatticeAddCommGroup](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Normed/Order/Lattice.html#NormedLatticeAddCommGroup) precisely because of `<`.
Thanks this is really helpful, I'll try these suggestions!

Sorry for the delay, teaching and grants have had me busy! I've had another go at the lemmas. I have left a couple of comments to see if anyone has a good idea as to what to name the lemma and also if there is an easier way to get the le version.
I would phrase `hg` as `BddAbove ((x ↦ (g x).re) '' K)`. And what's special about the `atTop` filter?

```suggestion
lemma tendstoUniformlyOn_iff_restrict {K : Set α} : TendstoUniformlyOn F f p K ↔
```

I'm surprised we don't have this. Does `apply?` give anything?
unfortunately not :(

Couple of comments here.
- In the statement `n` has type `Finset \iota` while elsewhere in the proof it has type `\iota`. A different letter would be preferable
- The `filter_upwards` tactic is very very useful. You should never be manually intersecting sets to prove an `eventually` statement!
- You take `hu.norm` unnecessarily and then have to un-do it later by using `Real.le_norm_self`. Just use `hu` directly and the final step is simpler.
- You are defining a lemma in the `Complex` namespace so you can omit the `Complex.` prefix on existing declarations (like `log`). 

Here's my suggestion:
```suggestion
lemma Complex.tendstoUniformlyOn_tsum_log_one_add {α : Type*} {f : ι → α → ℂ} (K : Set α)
    {u : ι → ℝ} (hu : Summable u) (h : ∀ᶠ n in cofinite, ∀ x ∈ K, ‖f n x‖ ≤ u n) :
    TendstoUniformlyOn (fun s a ↦ ∑ i ∈ s, log (1 + f i a)) (fun a ↦ ∑' i, log (1 + f i a)) 
    atTop K := by
  apply tendstoUniformlyOn_tsum_of_cofinite_eventually <| hu.mul_left (3 / 2)
  filter_upwards [h, hu.tendsto_cofinite_zero.eventually_le_const one_half_pos] with n hn hn' x hx
    using (norm_log_one_add_half_le_self <| (hn x hx).trans hn').trans (by simpa using hn x hx)
```

I can't write this as a suggestion (since the PR has a mixture of deleted and edited lines), but here is a 2-line proof:
```lean
lemma Complex.tendstoUniformlyOn_tsum_nat_log_one_add {α : Type*} {f : ℕ → α → ℂ} (K : Set α)
    {u : ℕ → ℝ} (hu : Summable u) (h : ∀ᶠ n in atTop, ∀ x ∈ K, ‖f n x‖ ≤ u n) :
    TendstoUniformlyOn (fun n a ↦ ∑ i ∈ Finset.range n, log (1 + f i a)) 
    (fun a ↦ ∑' i : ℕ, log (1 + f i a)) atTop K :=
  fun v hv ↦ tendsto_finset_range.eventually 
    <| tendstoUniformlyOn_tsum_log_one_add K hu (Nat.cofinite_eq_atTop ▸ h) v hv
```
I am not sure `Topology/Algebra` is the best place for this file given that it imports stuff from `Analysis`.
You've already got `Complex` open so there's no need for the `open scoped`.

I suggest `TendstoUniformlyOn.eventually_forall_lt` for the name. The problem is that this will upset `to_additive` because nothing involving the group structure appears in the name; and that's for good reason – the statement doesn't use the group structure either!

I had a stab at proving it without the group-theoretic assumptions but it didn't work; I found I was needing something to tie the uniformity and order structures together – it would be sufficient to show that `{(a, b) | a ≤ T → b < V} ∈ uniformity β`. Is there a notion of an `OrderUniformity`, I wonder?

Suggest making `f` implicit in the statement (because of `hf`).
See [#maths > Ordered uniform spaces?](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/116395-maths/topic/Ordered.20uniform.20spaces.3F) for discussion on this point.

```suggestion
  rw [tendstoUniformlyOn_iff_tendsto] at hf
```
Here we have a ⟨ ⟩ pattern nested inside another, can it be restructured to avoid that? Also the `simpa only` is terminal so it doesn't need to be squeezed, which gets you a few golf points.

```suggestion
  filter_upwards [hf.eventually_lt_mul_const htv hg] with i hi x hx using (hi x hx).le
```
There is a TODO in the heading of this file which looks like it may now have been fixed.

```suggestion
# Uniform convergence of products of functions

We gather some results about the uniform convergence of infinite products, in particular those of
the form `∏' i, (1 + f i x)` for a sequence `f` of functions.
```

These typeclass assumptions are the same wherever β appears so you can move them to section-level variables to avoid repetition. Moreover, `AddXXXStrictMono` and `AddXXXMono` are equivalent for linear orders, so you can choose either, but it seems strange to mix them (I suggest using the one that's shorter to type!)

```suggestion
    {f : ι → α → β} {p : Filter ι} {g : α → β} {K : Set α} {s t : β} (htv : s < t)
    (hf : TendstoUniformlyOn f g p K) (hg : ∀ x ∈ K, g x ≤ s) :
    ∀ᶠ i in p, ∀ x ∈ K, f i x < t := by
```
This is just cosmetic but I find it helps to improve readability. In particular, it's best to 

- use capital letters only for "container" variables (types or sets) and lowercase for other variables
- use consecutive letters for variables playing similar roles (instead of `T` and `V`)
- use matching letters where possible (so a generic element of type `ι` is `i`, not `n`)
- omit type ascriptions when not needed (since `p` is a filter on `ι`, the type of `i` in `∀ᶠ i in p` is clear)

I guess I stuggle to see the consistency elsewhere in mathlib, so I'm never quite sure about some things. I agree with what you are saying though, but for example, you say 'K' is fine for sets, but the library style guides say 's, t, ... for sets' but we use upper case for sets all the time.

The general rule is "capital letters for types, lowercase letters for terms"; but sets are occasionally tolerated as an exception to this rule – using `x` for a generic element of the set `X` is so obviously natural that the rules are bent to allow it. So the alternative convention "Greek for types, capital for sets, lowercase for elements" is common, particularly in analysis / topology. But I do agree this rule is less clear-cut than the other ones.

"Seeing the consistency in mathlib" is indeed not easy, since the coding conventions have shifted over time and code is not always retrospectively re-styled to adapt to changes (e.g. there is still a lot of suboptimal formatting hanging around from the lean3 port). Also, the review process is not perfect; the fact that one reviewer once approved something does not mean it is always allowed in all subsequent contributions.

```suggestion
  rw [eventually_prod_principal_iff] at *
  filter_upwards [hf2] with i hi x hx
  simpa using add_lt_add_of_le_of_lt (hg x hx) (hi x hx)
```

Ok so this is a bit confusing to me. This looks nicer but is slower in terms of heartbeats, it goes from 5815 to 6515, which isn't much, but I'm normally prioritising speed over other things, what's the rule of thumb here?

The difference here, 700 heartbeats, translates to something like 0.2 sec on my machine.

I think there is general consensus that readability / maintainability should be prioritized over speed. E.g. I refer you to the discussion on Zulip not long back introducing a new rule that terminal simps should _never_ be squeezed (not the same specific issue as here, but the same general trade-off, prioritizing other goals over speed). 

[Just to clarify, here I'm talking about "localized" speed issues, affecting a single proof, rather than things like typeclass-synthesis issues that can be a performance drag across big swathes of the library.]

```suggestion
  have hf2 := hf (fun x ↦ -x.1 + x.2 < -s + t) ⟨_, (isOpen_gt' (-s + t)).mem_nhds (by simp [htv]),
    fun y hy a b hab => (hab.symm ▸ hy :)⟩
```
(for compatibility with renamings above)
`f` can be implicit here. Please rename `T, V` as above
please modify as above

This proof seems very convoluted for no good reason, e.g. you rewrite with `← tendstoUniformlyOn_univ` and then close the goal with `exact w2`, but the proof of `w2` begins with `tendstoUniformlyOn_univ.mpr`, so these two steps just cancel each other out. Please, try to write proofs a little more straightforwardly!

A somewhat more direct proof is the following:
```suggestion
lemma tendstoUniformlyOn_comp_cexp {p : Filter ι} {f : ι → α → ℂ} {g : α → ℂ}
    {K : Set α} (hf : TendstoUniformlyOn f g p K) (hg : BddAbove <| (fun x ↦ (g x).re) '' K) :
    TendstoUniformlyOn (cexp ∘ f ·) (cexp ∘ g) p K := by
  obtain ⟨T, hT⟩ : ∃ T, ∀ x ∈ K, (g x).re ≤ T := hg.imp fun _ h ↦ by simpa [mem_upperBounds] using h
  have : ∀ᶠ i in p, ∀ x ∈ K, (f i x).re ≤ T + 1 := hf.re.eventually_forall_le (lt_add_one T) hT
  rw [tendstouniformlyOn_iff_restrict]
  refine (UniformContinuousOn.cexp _).comp_tendstoUniformly_eventually _ _ _ (by simpa) ?_ 
    (tendstouniformlyOn_iff_restrict.mp hf)
  simpa using fun a ha ↦ (hT a ha).trans (lt_add_one T).le
```
I'm giving the types explicitly in the `obtain` and `have` for readability (in your version it is very non-obvious to the reader what `hT` actually says after that `simp only` call). 

The proof would be substantially simpler if we had a lemma `comp_tendstoUniformlyOn_eventually` which would save flipping back+forth with `tendstouniformlyOn_iff_restrict`.
Please get into the habit of, whenever you see a pair of brackets, trying deleting them to check if they are needed.
... and the same for explicit type-ascriptions (`a` can't be anything else since it's the second argument to `f`).

In the same declaration you once use `n` for a generic term of `ι` and then for a generic `Finset ι`. Neither is an ideal choice and the combination is worse (the reader will naturally expect the same letter has the same type throughout the statement).

"The version" of what? Please specify. Moreover, why do you require here that the bound on `f` holds for _all_ `n`, not just eventually as in the previous lemma? This complicates the proof while also weakening the statement – you lose both ways.

```suggestion
lemma tendstoUniformlyOn_tprod_nat [TopologicalSpace α] {f : ℕ → α → ℂ} {K : Set α}
    (hK : IsCompact K) {u : ℕ → ℝ} (hu : Summable u) (h : ∀ n x, x ∈ K → ‖f n x‖ ≤ u n)
    (hfn : ∀ x ∈ K, ∀ n, 1 + f n x ≠ 0) (hcts : ∀ n, ContinuousOn (f n) K) :
    TendstoUniformlyOn (fun n a ↦ ∏ i ∈ Finset.range n, (1 + f i a))
    (fun a ↦ ∏' i, (1 + f i a)) atTop K := by
  refine tendstoUniformlyOn_tprod_nat_of_clog ?_ ?_ hfn (hK.bddAbove_image ?_)
  · exact fun x hx ↦ summable_log_one_add_of_summable (summable_norm_iff.mp
      (.of_nonneg_of_le (fun b ↦ norm_nonneg (f b x)) (fun _ ↦ h _ _ hx) hu))
  · exact tendstoUniformlyOn_tsum_log_one_add K hu (Eventually.of_forall h)
  · apply (tendstoUniformlyOn_tsum_nat_log_one_add K hu (.of_forall h)).re.continuousOn
    filter_upwards with n
    simp only [re_sum, log_re]
    refine continuousOn_finset_sum _ fun c _ ↦ ?_
    exact (continuousOn_const.add (hcts c)).norm.log (fun z hz ↦ by simpa using hfn z hz c)
```

When you have a `have` block and then the proof is a one-liner from that, you can almost always re-order it to avoid needing the `have` at all, as with `have H : ...` here. Also, I think it's very confusing to use `apply` with some *but not all* arguments specified as explicit blanks `?_`, because the resulting goals come out in the wrong order! Arguably this is an `apply` bug, but I think it's best to use `refine` as soon as you have one `?_`.
Both of these goals can be closed by `tauto`.

pullRequest.title: feat: TendstoUniformlyOn for tprod's
